weakness.name: CWE-1122
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-1122: Excessive Halstead Complexity The code is structured in a way that a Halstead complexity measure exceeds a desirable maximum.

weakness.name: CWE-200
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-200: Exposure of Sensitive Information to an Unauthorized Actor The product exposes sensitive information to an actor that is not explicitly authorized to have access to that information.

weakness.name: CWE-284
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-284: Improper Access Control The product does not restrict or incorrectly restricts access to a resource from an unauthorized actor.

weakness.name: CWE-287
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-287: Improper Authentication When an actor claims to have a given identity, the product does not prove or insufficiently proves that the claim is correct.

weakness.name: CWE-311
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-311: Missing Encryption of Sensitive Data The product does not encrypt sensitive or critical information before storage or transmission. The lack of proper data encryption passes up the guarantees of confidentiality, integrity, and accountability that properly implemented encryption conveys.

weakness.name: CWE-319
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-319: Cleartext Transmission of Sensitive Information The product transmits sensitive or security-critical data in cleartext in a communication channel that can be sniffed by unauthorized actors.

weakness.name: CWE-326
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-326: Inadequate Encryption Strength The product stores or transmits sensitive data using an encryption scheme that is theoretically sound, but is not strong enough for the level of protection required. A weak encryption scheme can be subjected to brute force attacks that have a reasonable chance of succeeding using current attack methods and resources.

weakness.name: CWE-693
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-693: Protection Mechanism Failure The product does not use or incorrectly uses a protection mechanism that provides sufficient defense against directed attacks against the product. This weakness covers three distinct situations. A "missing" protection mechanism occurs when the application does not define any mechanism against a certain class of attack. An "insufficient" protection mechanism might provide some defenses - for example, against the most common attacks - but it does not protect against everything that is intended. Finally, an "ignored" mechanism occurs when a mechanism is available and in active use within the product, but the developer has not applied it in some code path.

weakness.name: CWE-798
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-798: Use of Hard-coded Credentials The product contains hard-coded credentials, such as a password or cryptographic key, which it uses for its own inbound authentication, outbound communication to external components, or encryption of internal data.

weakness.name: CWE-926
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-926: Improper Export of Android Application Components The Android application exports a component for use by other applications, but does not properly restrict which applications can launch the component or access the data it contains.

countermeasure.name: Configure automatic mobile OS updates
countermeasure.desc:
Implement and regularly update automatic mobile OS updates on all mobile devices to ensure they are running the latest secure versions of their operating systems. This control minimizes exposure to vulnerabilities by promptly applying critical patches and security improvements as they are released. Developers and DevOps engineers should configure mobile device management (MDM) solutions or native OS settings to enforce automatic updates and continuously monitor update compliance across the device fleet.

Implementation Steps:

Enable Auto-Updates:
Configure mobile devices to automatically download and install OS updates as soon as they are available.

Deploy Centralized Update Policies:
Use MDM solutions to enforce and manage update policies across all mobile devices, ensuring uniform compliance.

Monitor Update Compliance:
Regularly audit update logs and compliance reports to verify that all devices are running the latest OS versions and apply remediation if discrepancies are found.

References:

  • Android Enterprise Updates

standard.ref: Contract Requirements for Service Providers and Contractors (a)
ID.RA-1: Asset vulnerabilities are identified and documented
PR.IP-12: A vulnerability management plan is developed and implemented

countermeasure.name: Deploy mobile anti-malware solutions
countermeasure.desc:
Implement and regularly update mobile anti-malware solutions on all mobile devices to detect, prevent, and remediate malware infections that could compromise the device's security. This control ensures that reputable anti-malware software with real-time scanning and periodic full-device scans is installed and maintained. Developers and DevOps engineers should use mobile device management (MDM) tools to enforce consistent deployment, configuration, and automatic updates of malware definitions across the entire mobile device fleet.

Implementation Steps:

Install Reputable Anti-Malware Software:
Deploy trusted anti-malware applications on all mobile devices via MDM solutions or approved installation packages.

Enable Real-Time Scanning:
Configure the anti-malware solution to continuously monitor device activity and block potential threats in real time.

Schedule Regular Full-Device Scans:
Set up periodic scans to identify and remediate any dormant or emerging malware infections.

Automate Malware Definition Updates:
Ensure the anti-malware software is configured to automatically update its threat definitions to keep pace with emerging threats.

Monitor and Audit Compliance:
Use centralized management tools to verify that all devices maintain up-to-date anti-malware protection and address any compliance issues promptly.

References:

  • NIST SP 800-83: Guide to Malware Incident Prevention and Handling

standard.ref: Contract Requirements for Service Providers and Contractors (a)
ID.RA-1: Asset vulnerabilities are identified and documented
PR.IP-12: A vulnerability management plan is developed and implemented

countermeasure.name: Deploy mobile anti-phishing protection
countermeasure.desc:
Implement and regularly update anti-phishing protection on all mobile devices to detect and block phishing attempts targeting mobile users. This control leverages built-in email and browser security features, integrates threat intelligence feeds, and enforces centralized policies to ensure that phishing attacks are promptly identified and mitigated. Developers and DevOps engineers should use mobile device management (MDM) solutions to deploy and monitor anti-phishing configurations consistently across the entire mobile device fleet.

Implementation Steps:

Enable Built-In Anti-Phishing Features:
Activate anti-phishing functionalities available in mobile email and browser applications, ensuring they are properly configured to warn users of suspicious links and communications.

Integrate Threat Intelligence Feeds:
Connect to reputable threat intelligence services (e.g., Google Safe Browsing) to keep phishing detection databases current with emerging phishing trends.

Deploy Centralized Policies:
Use MDM tools to enforce uniform anti-phishing configurations and update policies across all mobile devices, ensuring consistent protection.

Conduct Regular Testing:
Periodically simulate phishing attacks and audit mobile device logs to verify the effectiveness of anti-phishing measures and adjust configurations as needed.

References:

  • Google Safe Browsing API

standard.ref: Contract Requirements for Service Providers and Contractors (a)
ID.RA-1: Asset vulnerabilities are identified and documented
PR.IP-12: A vulnerability management plan is developed and implemented

countermeasure.name: Enable remote wipe and tracking features
countermeasure.desc:
Implement and regularly update remote wipe and tracking features on all mobile devices to protect sensitive data in the event of device loss or theft. This control utilizes mobile device management (MDM) solutions to enable real-time tracking, location monitoring, and the ability to remotely erase data. By ensuring that these features are active and properly configured, organizations can quickly respond to incidents of loss or theft, mitigating the risk of unauthorized data access and reducing overall impact.

Implementation Steps:

Configure Remote Wipe:
Enable and enforce remote wipe capabilities via MDM settings to allow for immediate data erasure when a device is lost or compromised.

Set Up Device Tracking:
Activate tracking and location reporting features on mobile devices to facilitate quick identification and recovery in case of theft.

Establish Incident Response Procedures:
Define and document processes for initiating remote wipe and tracking actions, including regular testing and drills to ensure readiness.

Monitor and Audit Compliance:
Use centralized management tools to verify that remote wipe and tracking features are enabled across all devices and perform periodic audits to ensure their effectiveness.

References:

  • NIST SP 800-124 Revision 1: Guidelines for Managing the Security of Mobile Devices

standard.ref: PR.DS-3: Assets are formally managed throughout removal, transfers, and disposition
PR.IP-6: Data is destroyed according to policy
PR.PT-2: Removable media is protected and its use restricted according to policy

countermeasure.name: Enforce app store whitelisting and robust app vetting
countermeasure.desc:
Implement and regularly update app store whitelisting and robust app vetting policies on all mobile devices to ensure that only approved and trusted applications are installed. This control helps mitigate the risk of malicious apps by restricting installations to vetted sources and enforcing strict approval processes. Developers and DevOps engineers should leverage mobile device management (MDM) solutions to enforce these policies and continuously monitor app installations.

Implementation Steps:

Establish an App Whitelist:
Identify and maintain a list of approved app stores or specific applications that have been thoroughly vetted for security and compliance.

Deploy Centralized App Management:
Utilize MDM solutions to enforce the whitelist across all mobile devices, ensuring that only approved apps can be installed.

Conduct Robust App Vetting:
Evaluate applications for security vulnerabilities, permissions, and overall risk before adding them to the whitelist, and periodically review the approved apps for compliance.

Monitor and Audit App Installations:
Regularly audit mobile devices for unauthorized apps and update the whitelist based on emerging threats and updated security policies.

References:

  • Apple App Store Review Guidelines

standard.ref: PR.DS-6: Integrity checking mechanisms are used to verify software, firmware, and information integrity

countermeasure.name: Enforce regular app updates and conduct vulnerability scanning
countermeasure.desc:
Implement and regularly update mobile applications along with conducting periodic vulnerability scanning on all mobile devices to ensure that installed apps remain secure and free of known vulnerabilities. This control minimizes the risk of exploitation through outdated or misconfigured applications by automating app updates and integrating vulnerability assessments into the mobile device management process. Developers and DevOps engineers should leverage centralized management tools to enforce update policies and deploy vulnerability scanning solutions to identify and remediate security issues in installed apps.

Implementation Steps:

Enable Auto-Updates for Mobile Apps:
Configure mobile devices and app stores to automatically update applications as new, secure versions are released.

Deploy Vulnerability Scanning Tools:
Utilize mobile security tools to conduct regular vulnerability scans on installed applications, identifying potential weaknesses or misconfigurations.

Integrate with Mobile Device Management (MDM):
Use MDM solutions to enforce app update policies and schedule regular vulnerability assessments across all devices.

Monitor, Report, and Remediate:
Establish processes to monitor scan results, report identified vulnerabilities, and quickly remediate issues through updates or configuration changes.

References:

  • OWASP Mobile Security Testing Guide

countermeasure.name: Implement secure backup and data synchronization protocols
countermeasure.desc:
Implement and regularly update secure backup and data synchronization protocols on all mobile devices to protect sensitive data during storage and transit. This control ensures that backup and synchronization processes use strong encryption, secure communication channels, and trusted storage solutions. Developers and DevOps engineers should configure mobile device management (MDM) tools to enforce secure backup settings and continuously monitor synchronization processes for compliance with organizational security policies.

Implementation Steps:

Enable Encrypted Backups:
Configure mobile devices to encrypt data before backup and ensure that backups are stored using strong encryption standards.

Use Secure Synchronization Channels:
Ensure data synchronization occurs over secure channels (e.g., HTTPS/TLS) to prevent interception during transit.

Enforce Backup Policies via MDM:
Leverage MDM solutions to deploy and enforce secure backup and synchronization settings across all mobile devices.

Monitor and Audit Backup Processes:
Regularly review backup logs and synchronization records to verify that data is securely handled and to identify any anomalies.

References:

  • NIST SP 800-111: Guide to Storage Encryption Technologies

countermeasure.name: Implement secure data storage and device encryption
countermeasure.desc:
Implement and regularly update secure data storage and device encryption on all mobile devices to safeguard sensitive information from unauthorized access. This control ensures that all locally stored data is encrypted using robust encryption standards, protecting it even if the device is lost or stolen. Developers and DevOps engineers should enforce encryption policies via mobile device management (MDM) solutions, configure devices for full-disk encryption, and use secure storage APIs provided by the operating system. Regular audits and updates are essential to ensure compliance and address emerging security threats.

Implementation Steps:

Configure Full-Disk Encryption:
Enable full-disk encryption on all mobile devices to ensure that all data at rest is secured.

Enforce MDM Policies:
Use MDM solutions to deploy and enforce secure encryption settings across the device fleet.

Leverage Secure Storage APIs:
Utilize OS-provided secure storage mechanisms for sensitive data and application credentials.

Manage Encryption Keys Securely:
Implement robust key management practices to protect encryption keys from unauthorized access.

Audit and Monitor Compliance:
Regularly review encryption settings and conduct audits to verify that encryption policies are consistently applied.

References:

  • NIST SP 800-111: Guide to Storage Encryption Technologies

standard.ref: SC-12 CRYPTOGRAPHIC KEY ESTABLISHMENT AND MANAGEMENT

customField.value: ATT&CK Mobile - M1009 - Encrypt Network Traffic

countermeasure.name: Implement strong device authentication
countermeasure.desc:
Implement and regularly update strong device authentication on all mobile devices to ensure that only authorized users can access the device and its sensitive data. This control involves enforcing robust authentication mechanismssuch as multi-factor authentication (MFA), complex passcodes, and biometric verificationto mitigate the risk of unauthorized access. Developers and DevOps engineers should leverage mobile device management (MDM) solutions and enterprise identity providers to enforce and monitor these authentication policies across all devices.

Implementation Steps:

Enforce Robust Passcode Policies:
Configure devices to require complex passcodes with a minimum length and periodic changes.

Enable Biometric Authentication:
Utilize built-in biometric features (e.g., fingerprint or facial recognition) to add an additional layer of security.

Deploy Multi-Factor Authentication (MFA):
Integrate MFA for accessing sensitive applications and data on mobile devices.

Integrate with Enterprise Identity Providers:
Use centralized authentication systems via MDM to enforce consistent policies and monitor compliance across the device fleet.

Regularly Audit Authentication Settings:
Conduct periodic reviews and audits to ensure that authentication configurations remain effective and aligned with evolving security requirements.

References:

  • NIST SP 800-63B: Digital Identity Guidelines

countermeasure.name: Use VPN and enforce encrypted communication channels
countermeasure.desc:
Implement and regularly update Virtual Private Network (VPN) configurations and enforce encrypted communication channels on all mobile devices to secure data in transit. This control ensures that all network communications are routed through secure tunnels and that robust encryption protocols (e.g., TLS) are applied, protecting against eavesdropping and man-in-the-middle attacks. Developers and DevOps engineers should leverage mobile device management (MDM) solutions to deploy VPN configurations and enforce encryption standards consistently across the device fleet.

Implementation Steps:

Deploy VPN Solutions:
Configure and enforce the use of reputable VPN solutions on all mobile devices to create secure tunnels for network traffic.

Enable Strong Encryption Protocols:
Ensure that both VPN connections and general network communications use the latest approved encryption protocols (e.g., TLS 1.2/1.3).

Centralized Management:
Use MDM solutions to enforce VPN usage and encrypted communication policies across all mobile devices, and monitor compliance regularly.

Test and Audit:
Conduct periodic security audits and penetration testing to validate that VPN and encrypted channels are correctly implemented and functioning as intended.

References:

  • NIST Special Publication 800-52 Revision 2

usecase.name: Elevation of Privilege
usecase.desc: Elevation of privilege involves an attacker gaining higher levels of access or permissions than intended. By exploiting vulnerabilities, attackers can escalate their privileges within a system to perform unauthorized actions or access sensitive data.

threat.name: Exploitation of vulnerabilities in installed apps
threat.desc:
General Threat Description:
This threat involves adversaries identifying and exploiting weaknesses in the mobile applications installed on a device. Vulnerabilities may arise from insecure coding practices, outdated libraries, or improper permission configurations, allowing attackers to compromise app functionality and gain unauthorized access to sensitive data stored on the mobile device.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors:

  • Malicious developers or adversaries who modify legitimate applications to include harmful code.
  • Attackers leveraging known vulnerabilities in third-party libraries integrated into mobile apps.
  • Distribution of compromised or counterfeit apps through both official and unofficial app stores.
  • Exploitation of insecure app permissions and data storage practices within vulnerable applications.

Impacts:

  • Unauthorized access to personal or sensitive data stored by the apps or on the device.
  • Data exfiltration, leading to privacy breaches and potential financial loss.
  • Compromise of device integrity, allowing for further exploitation and lateral movement within networks.
  • Erosion of user trust, resulting in reputational damage for app developers and service providers.

Example Attack Scenarios:

  • An attacker discovers a buffer overflow vulnerability in a widely used social media app. By exploiting this flaw, the attacker executes malicious code that accesses and exfiltrates the user's contacts and messages.
  • A modified version of a popular banking app is distributed through a third-party app store. Once installed, the malicious app exploits insecure data storage practices to harvest sensitive financial information, which is then sent to the attackers server.

customField.value: ATT&CK Mobile - T1455 - Exploit Baseband Vulnerability

usecase.name: Information Disclosure
usecase.desc: Information disclosure occurs when sensitive data is exposed to unauthorized parties. This can include unauthorized access to confidential information, such as personal data, financial records, or intellectual property.

threat.name: Device theft or loss leading to data compromise
threat.desc:
General Threat Description:
This threat involves the potential exposure and unauthorized access of sensitive data when a mobile device is lost or stolen. If the device is not secured with proper encryption and access controls, attackers gaining physical access can extract confidential information, leading to significant data breaches.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors:

  • Opportunistic criminals targeting lost or stolen devices
  • Unauthorized individuals exploiting weak or absent access controls on the device
  • Attackers leveraging physical access to bypass security measures such as screen locks or encryption

Impacts:

  • Unauthorized access to personal, financial, or corporate data
  • Increased risk of identity theft, financial fraud, and further unauthorized activities
  • Potential reputational and financial damage for individuals and organizations

Example Attack Scenarios:

  • A mobile device is left unattended in a public place; an opportunistic thief retrieves the device, bypasses its weak screen lock, and accesses stored sensitive data.
  • A stolen mobile device without full-disk encryption allows an attacker to extract confidential business information and personal data, which is then used for further malicious activities.

threat.name: Interception of network communications
threat.desc:
General Threat Description:
This threat involves adversaries intercepting and potentially altering data transmitted between a mobile device and external networks. Attackers exploit insecure or misconfigured network channels to capture sensitive information and may manipulate the data to facilitate further attacks.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors:

  • Cybercriminals deploying rogue Wi-Fi access points or hotspots
  • Man-in-the-middle attackers exploiting unencrypted network protocols
  • Hackers leveraging vulnerabilities in mobile operating systems or network stacks
  • Adversaries compromising network devices such as routers

Impacts:

  • Unauthorized access to sensitive data such as login credentials, financial information, or personal details
  • Data manipulation leading to fraudulent transactions or misinformation
  • Compromised privacy and erosion of user trust in mobile connectivity
  • Increased risk of subsequent targeted attacks due to exposed session data

Example Attack Scenarios:

  • A mobile device connects to a public Wi-Fi network, where an attacker uses a rogue access point to intercept and log sensitive communications, capturing login credentials and personal data.
  • An attacker exploits a vulnerability in the mobile OS network stack to perform a man-in-the-middle attack, altering data exchanged between the device and a secure server, resulting in unauthorized transactions.

customField.value: ATT&CK Mobile - T1438 - Exfiltration Over Other Network Medium

threat.name: Exposure of sensitive data due to insecure local storage
threat.desc:
General Threat Description:
This threat involves the risk that sensitive data stored locally on mobile devices may be accessible to unauthorized users due to insecure storage practices. Weak local storage mechanisms, such as unencrypted files or poorly secured databases, can expose personal, financial, or corporate data if the device is compromised or accessed by malicious actors.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors:

  • Cybercriminals targeting unencrypted or misconfigured storage systems on mobile devices
  • Malicious applications that gain access to local storage areas containing sensitive information
  • Attackers leveraging physical access to the device or exploiting vulnerabilities in the operating system to retrieve data
  • Insider threats with legitimate access to the device who misuse stored data

Impacts:

  • Unauthorized access to and exfiltration of sensitive information
  • Increased risk of identity theft, financial fraud, or corporate espionage
  • Compromise of user privacy and potential regulatory or legal consequences for organizations
  • Erosion of user trust in the security of mobile applications and services

Example Attack Scenarios:

  • An attacker exploits a vulnerability in a mobile app that stores user credentials in plain text, allowing them to extract this sensitive information directly from the devices local storage.
  • A lost or stolen device without proper encryption on its local storage is accessed by unauthorized users, leading to the extraction of confidential personal and corporate data.

customField.value: ATT&CK Mobile - T1533 - Data from Local System

threat.name: Data leakage via insecure backup or synchronization services
threat.desc:
General Threat Description:
This threat involves the risk that sensitive data stored on mobile devices is exposed through insecure backup or synchronization services. Weaknesses in the configuration or implementation of these services may allow unauthorized access or interception of data during backup or synchronization processes.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors:

  • Cybercriminals exploiting misconfigured or unsecured cloud backup services.
  • Attackers intercepting data during transmission between the mobile device and backup servers.
  • Malicious insiders with access to backup systems.
  • Exploitation of vulnerabilities in synchronization protocols or software.

Impacts:

  • Unauthorized access to personal, corporate, or sensitive data.
  • Data theft, leading to privacy breaches and potential financial or reputational damage.
  • Increased risk of subsequent attacks if leaked data includes authentication credentials or sensitive operational information.

Example Attack Scenarios:

  • An attacker identifies a misconfigured cloud backup service used by a mobile device client, gaining access to unencrypted backup files containing sensitive user data.
  • A mobile device synchronizes data with a cloud service over an unencrypted connection, allowing a man-in-the-middle attacker to intercept and exfiltrate confidential information.

customField.value: ATT&CK Mobile - T1470 - Obtain Device Cloud Backups

threat.name: Malware infections on the mobile device
threat.desc:
General Threat Description:
This threat involves the introduction and execution of malicious software on mobile devices, which can compromise device functionality, steal sensitive data, or provide a foothold for further attacks. Malware can be delivered through various channels, and once installed, it may operate covertly to disrupt services, exfiltrate information, or control the device remotely.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors:

  • Cybercriminals distributing malicious apps through unofficial app stores or compromised legitimate apps.
  • Phishing campaigns that trick users into downloading malware-laden attachments or links.
  • Drive-by downloads from compromised or malicious websites accessed via the mobile device.
  • Exploitation of vulnerabilities in mobile operating systems and applications to install malware without user consent.

Impacts:

  • Unauthorized access to sensitive data including personal, financial, or corporate information.
  • Degradation of device performance, data loss, and system instability.
  • Potential for the malware to spread laterally within networks or facilitate further cyberattacks.
  • Loss of user privacy and increased risk of identity theft or financial fraud.

Example Attack Scenarios:

  • A user installs an app from an unofficial app store that appears legitimate but contains hidden malware, which then records keystrokes and sends sensitive information to a remote attacker.
  • An attacker sends a phishing message with a link to a compromised website; when the user visits the site, a drive-by download installs malware on the device, enabling the attacker to take control of the device remotely.

customField.value: ATT&CK Mobile - T1473 - Malicious or Vulnerable Built-in Device Functionality

usecase.name: Spoofing
usecase.desc: Spoofing involves an attacker pretending to be someone else by falsifying data or identity. This can include spoofing email addresses, IP addresses, or user identities to gain unauthorized access to systems or information.

threat.name: Unauthorized access due to weak device authentication
threat.desc:
General Threat Description:
This threat involves adversaries exploiting insufficient authentication measures on mobile devices, such as weak PINs, passwords, or absence of biometric verification, to gain unauthorized access. Without robust authentication, attackers can easily bypass device security, potentially accessing sensitive data and applications stored on the device.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors:

  • Cybercriminals using brute force or credential stuffing attacks against weak passwords or PINs.
  • Insider threats or unauthorized individuals exploiting minimal authentication controls on lost or shared devices.
  • Attackers leveraging social engineering tactics to trick users into revealing their authentication credentials.

Impacts:

  • Unauthorized access to sensitive personal or corporate data stored on the mobile device.
  • Potential for further lateral movement within an organization if the device is connected to corporate networks.
  • Increased risk of identity theft, financial fraud, and privacy breaches.
  • Compromise of device integrity, leading to installation of malware or unauthorized configuration changes.

Example Attack Scenarios:

  • An attacker uses a brute force tool to systematically guess a weak 4-digit PIN on a mobile device, eventually gaining access and extracting sensitive information.
  • A lost or unattended mobile device with weak authentication is retrieved by an unauthorized individual who accesses stored emails, contacts, and financial applications, resulting in data theft or misuse.

customField.value: ATT&CK Mobile - T1626.001 - Device Administrator Permissions

threat.name: Phishing attacks targeting mobile users
threat.desc:
General Threat Description:
This threat involves adversaries using deceptive techniques to lure mobile device users into providing sensitive information or downloading malicious content. Phishing attacks on mobile devices often exploit the smaller screen size and limited context to trick users into trusting fraudulent messages, emails, or websites that mimic legitimate services.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors:

  • Cybercriminals employing social engineering tactics via SMS, email, or instant messaging.
  • Malicious websites or in-app advertisements that redirect users to counterfeit login pages.
  • Adversaries using cloned or lookalike mobile apps designed to capture user credentials.
  • Attackers leveraging push notifications or pop-up messages within compromised apps.

Impacts:

  • Unauthorized access to user accounts and sensitive data such as passwords, financial details, or personal information.
  • Installation of additional malware through fraudulent links or app downloads.
  • Erosion of user trust in mobile communications and associated services.
  • Potential financial loss and privacy breaches resulting from compromised credentials.

Example Attack Scenarios:

  • A mobile user receives a text message that appears to be from their bank, prompting them to click a link that directs them to a fraudulent website mimicking the banks login page, where their credentials are harvested.
  • An attacker sends a phishing email to a mobile device user containing a link to a cloned version of a popular social media app; once the user logs in, their account details are captured and misused.

usecase.name: Tampering
usecase.desc: Tampering refers to unauthorized modification of data or systems. Attackers may alter data in transit or modify software components to introduce vulnerabilities or compromise the integrity of the system.

threat.name: Infiltration of malicious applications
threat.desc:
General Threat Description:
This threat involves adversaries distributing malicious applications that appear legitimate to mobile device users. These apps may be designed to steal sensitive data, deliver malware, or gain unauthorized access to device functions. The infiltration often occurs through unofficial app stores or by disguising malware as a benign application, bypassing traditional security checks.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors:

  • Cybercriminals creating and distributing malicious apps through third-party or compromised official app stores.
  • Attackers leveraging social engineering tactics to convince users to download and install fraudulent applications.
  • Malicious developers embedding harmful code into apps that mimic legitimate functionalities.
  • Exploitation of vulnerabilities in app vetting processes to bypass security filters.

Impacts:

  • Unauthorized access to sensitive personal or corporate data stored on the mobile device.
  • Installation of additional malware that can further compromise device security.
  • Financial loss due to fraudulent transactions or identity theft.
  • Erosion of user trust in mobile applications and potential reputational damage for affected organizations.

Example Attack Scenarios:

  • A user downloads an application from an unofficial app store that appears to offer useful features but secretly collects personal data and transmits it to a remote server controlled by an attacker.
  • An attacker disguises a malicious app as a popular game, tricking users into installing it; once installed, the app gains access to contacts, messages, and location data, which are then exploited for targeted phishing or identity theft.

customField.value: ATT&CK Mobile - T1630.001 - Uninstall Malicious Application

threat.name: Exploitation of unpatched mobile OS vulnerabilities
threat.desc:
General Threat Description:
This threat involves adversaries taking advantage of unpatched or outdated mobile operating system vulnerabilities. Without timely updates, known security flaws remain open to exploitation, allowing attackers to bypass security controls, gain unauthorized access, or execute arbitrary code on the device.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors:

  • Cybercriminals targeting devices running outdated mobile OS versions
  • State-sponsored attackers leveraging known or zero-day vulnerabilities
  • Automated attack tools scanning for vulnerable devices
  • Malicious applications exploiting OS flaws to escalate privileges

Impacts:

  • Unauthorized access to sensitive personal or corporate data
  • Complete device compromise, including installation of persistent malware
  • Potential for lateral movement within connected enterprise networks
  • Erosion of user trust and possible regulatory or financial repercussions

Example Attack Scenarios:

  • An attacker exploits a known vulnerability in an outdated mobile OS to bypass authentication, gaining root access and installing spyware to monitor user activity.
  • Automated malware targets devices with unpatched operating systems, exploiting the vulnerability to install ransomware that encrypts sensitive data and demands payment for decryption.

customField.value: ATT&CK Mobile - T1455 - Exploit Baseband Vulnerability

weakness.name: CWE-269
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-269: Improper Privilege Management The product does not properly assign, modify, track, or check privileges for an actor, creating an unintended sphere of control for that actor.

weakness.name: CWE-319
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-319: Cleartext Transmission of Sensitive Information The product transmits sensitive or security-critical data in cleartext in a communication channel that can be sniffed by unauthorized actors.

weakness.name: CWE-346
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-346: Origin Validation Error The product does not properly verify that the source of data or communication is valid.

weakness.name: CWE-778
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-778: Insufficient Logging When a security-critical event occurs, the product either does not record the event or omits important details about the event when logging it.

countermeasure.name: Apply least privilege for DNS record management
countermeasure.desc:
Use Google Cloud IAM roles and permissions to implement the principle of least privilege for DNS record management. Ensure that only authorized users with specific roles can modify DNS records. Assign permissions carefully, restricting access to users or services that need it to minimize the risk of unauthorized changes. Regularly review and audit permissions to ensure compliance with security best practices and remove excessive or outdated access rights.

For more details, refer to:

  • GCP IAM Best Practices

countermeasure.name: Configure DNS queries to use HTTPS for encrypted transmission
countermeasure.desc:
Ensure that all DNS queries are sent over HTTPS (DNS over HTTPS, or DoH) to protect data in transit from being intercepted or tampered with by malicious actors. By encrypting DNS traffic, you safeguard DNS queries and responses from potential man-in-the-middle (MitM) attacks and ensure that sensitive information is not exposed on the network. Regularly verify that all DNS traffic is encrypted using DoH to maintain a secure DNS environment.

For more details, refer to:

  • GCP DNS Security Documentation

countermeasure.name: Enable DNSSEC to authenticate DNS responses
countermeasure.desc:
Enable DNSSEC (Domain Name System Security Extensions) for your Cloud DNS managed zones to protect against DNS spoofing attacks. DNSSEC uses digital signatures to authenticate DNS responses, ensuring that clients only receive valid and untampered responses from authoritative DNS servers. Implement DNSSEC to prevent attackers from injecting fraudulent DNS data and redirecting traffic to malicious websites. Regularly monitor DNSSEC configurations to maintain a secure DNS environment.

For more details, refer to:

  • GCP DNSSEC Documentation

countermeasure.name: Enable logging for all DNS changes
countermeasure.desc:
Enable logging for all changes to DNS records in GCP to ensure a comprehensive audit trail of DNS modifications. Use Cloud Logging to track and monitor any changes made to DNS settings, and regularly review the logs to identify suspicious or unauthorized activity. Additionally, set up alerts to notify administrators of any unauthorized modifications or anomalies in real-time, enabling a prompt response to potential security threats.

For more details, refer to:

  • GCP Logging Best Practices

usecase.name: Repudiation
usecase.desc: Repudiation involves denying an action or event that has taken place. In a security context, repudiation threats can occur when a user denies performing a specific action, such as denying sending a message or making a transaction.

threat.name: Lack of logging for DNS changes
threat.desc:
General threat description
The lack of logging for DNS changes can result in unauthorized modifications going unnoticed. Without proper logging and monitoring, malicious actors or insider threats could alter DNS records, redirecting traffic or compromising services. Failure to detect such changes can lead to prolonged exposure to attacks.

Threat agents/Attack vectors

  • Threat Agents: Malicious insiders, external attackers with stolen credentials, or users with excessive privileges.
  • Attack Vectors: Unauthorized or unnoticed DNS record changes due to lack of logging or monitoring.

Impacts

  • DNS hijacking, redirecting traffic to malicious sites.
  • Service disruptions or unavailability of services due to incorrect DNS configurations.
  • Prolonged compromise due to delayed detection of malicious changes.

Example attack scenarios

  1. A malicious insider makes unauthorized changes to DNS records, redirecting traffic to a malicious site without being detected because DNS change logs are not monitored.
  2. An attacker with stolen credentials modifies DNS records to launch a phishing campaign, and the changes go unnoticed for days due to the lack of DNS logging and alerts.

usecase.name: Spoofing
usecase.desc: Spoofing involves an attacker pretending to be someone else by falsifying data or identity. This can include spoofing email addresses, IP addresses, or user identities to gain unauthorized access to systems or information.

threat.name: DNS cache poisoning
threat.desc:
General threat description
DNS cache poisoning occurs when an attacker manipulates the cache of a DNS resolver, injecting fraudulent IP addresses for legitimate domain names. This redirects users to malicious websites without their knowledge, leading to data theft, malware distribution, or phishing attacks. Without DNSSEC (Domain Name System Security Extensions), DNS responses are vulnerable to tampering, making cache poisoning a critical risk.

Threat agents/Attack vectors

  • Threat Agents: External attackers, compromised DNS resolvers, malicious insiders.
  • Attack Vectors: Exploiting weaknesses in DNS query/response processes to inject false information into DNS caches.

Impacts

  • Redirection of users to malicious websites, resulting in phishing, data theft, or malware infection.
  • Loss of customer trust and potential brand damage.
  • Compromise of critical infrastructure if services are redirected to attacker-controlled locations.

Example attack scenarios

  1. An attacker injects a fake IP address into the DNS cache of a resolver, causing users trying to visit a legitimate banking website to be redirected to a phishing site.
  2. A malicious actor exploits a vulnerability in a DNS server, poisoning its cache and redirecting traffic meant for a popular online service to a server under their control, where they steal user credentials.

threat.name: Man-in-the-middle attacks on DNS queries
threat.desc:
General threat description
A man-in-the-middle (MitM) attack on DNS queries occurs when an attacker intercepts or alters DNS requests and responses between the client and DNS server. By doing so, the attacker can redirect users to malicious websites, steal sensitive information, or disrupt services. DNS queries that are not encrypted or authenticated are particularly vulnerable to such attacks.

Threat agents/Attack vectors

  • Threat Agents: External attackers, malicious network intermediaries, or compromised routers.
  • Attack Vectors: Intercepting unencrypted DNS traffic, modifying DNS responses in transit, or spoofing DNS servers to redirect traffic.

Impacts

  • Redirection of users to fraudulent or malicious websites.
  • Data theft, including login credentials or sensitive user information.
  • Service disruption or compromise, resulting in downtime or reputational damage.

Example attack scenarios

  1. An attacker performs a MitM attack by intercepting DNS queries over an unsecured network and responds with malicious IP addresses, redirecting users trying to access a legitimate service to a fake site.
  2. A MitM attack targets public Wi-Fi users, intercepting DNS queries and altering responses to redirect users to a malicious website where their login credentials are stolen.

usecase.name: Tampering
usecase.desc: Tampering refers to unauthorized modification of data or systems. Attackers may alter data in transit or modify software components to introduce vulnerabilities or compromise the integrity of the system.

threat.name: Unauthorized modification of DNS records
threat.desc:
General threat description
Unauthorized modification of DNS records occurs when an attacker or unauthorized user gains access to modify DNS settings, redirecting traffic to malicious servers or disrupting services. DNS records control how domain names are resolved into IP addresses, and tampering with these records can lead to DNS hijacking, service outages, or data breaches.

Threat agents/Attack vectors

  • Threat Agents: External attackers, compromised accounts, malicious insiders.
  • Attack Vectors: Exploiting weak access controls, using stolen credentials, or leveraging misconfigured permissions to modify DNS records.

Impacts

  • DNS hijacking, redirecting traffic to malicious websites.
  • Service disruptions, causing unavailability of critical applications or services.
  • Data theft or phishing attacks, leading to financial loss and reputational damage.

Example attack scenarios

  1. An attacker gains unauthorized access to the DNS management console using stolen credentials and modifies DNS records to redirect website visitors to a malicious server for phishing.
  2. A malicious insider with excessive privileges changes DNS settings, causing a company's email traffic to be routed to an attacker-controlled server, leading to data interception.

weakness.name: CWE-200
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-200: Exposure of Sensitive Information to an Unauthorized Actor The product exposes sensitive information to an actor that is not explicitly authorized to have access to that information.

weakness.name: CWE-223
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-223: Omission of Security-relevant Information The product does not record or display information that would be important for identifying the source or nature of an attack, or determining if an action is safe.

weakness.name: CWE-284
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-284: Improper Access Control The product does not restrict or incorrectly restricts access to a resource from an unauthorized actor.

weakness.name: CWE-285
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-285: Improper Authorization The product does not perform or incorrectly performs an authorization check when an actor attempts to access a resource or perform an action.

weakness.name: CWE-693
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-693: Protection Mechanism Failure The product does not use or incorrectly uses a protection mechanism that provides sufficient defense against directed attacks against the product. This weakness covers three distinct situations. A "missing" protection mechanism occurs when the application does not define any mechanism against a certain class of attack. An "insufficient" protection mechanism might provide some defenses - for example, against the most common attacks - but it does not protect against everything that is intended. Finally, an "ignored" mechanism occurs when a mechanism is available and in active use within the product, but the developer has not applied it in some code path.

weakness.name: CWE-798
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-798: Use of Hard-coded Credentials The product contains hard-coded credentials, such as a password or cryptographic key, which it uses for its own inbound authentication, outbound communication to external components, or encryption of internal data.

countermeasure.name: Block all inbound port traffic from 0.0.0.0/0
countermeasure.desc:
To enhance the security of your Google Cloud Platform (GCP) Load Balancing setup, it is critical to implement network security rules that block all inbound traffic from untrusted sources. This is essential in minimizing exposure to potential attacks. Follow these steps to configure your network security rules effectively:

  1. Identify the untrusted sources: Determine which IP ranges are considered untrusted (e.g., 0.0.0.0/0). The default 0.0.0.0/0 represents all IPv4 addresses, and you should explicitly specify trusted sources to ensure only these can access your load balancer.

  2. Access the Google Cloud Console: Navigate to the Firewall rules page in your GCP console.

  3. Create or update firewall rules:

    • Select or create a rule to enforce that inbound traffic from the untrusted source range(s) is disallowed. You can edit existing rules or add new firewall rules as necessary.
    • Ensure your firewall rules are applied to the VMs behind your load balancer by specifying the appropriate network tags or service accounts.

  4. Configure your load balancer:

    • Ensure that the backend service of your load balancer is configured to only accept traffic that passes through the firewall rules. This can be done by associating the backend with secured networks and limiting access only to approved sources.
    • For HTTP(S) load balancing, enable the use of HTTPS traffic management features to further enhance security by requiring secure connections.

  5. Test the configuration: Regularly monitor and test your network security rules to ensure that your configuration effectively blocks inappropriate access and only allows access from trusted sources.

For more detailed information on setting up and maintaining secure load balancing configurations, refer to the GCP Load Balancing Best Practices. This document provides extensive guidance on secure configurations and management of Google Cloud Load Balancing.

countermeasure.name: Configure load balancing with zonal NEGs
countermeasure.desc:
To ensure high availability and improved performance in your application deployments on Google Cloud Platform (GCP), it is recommended to use zonal Network Endpoint Groups (NEGs) for distributing traffic efficiently across different zones. Follow these steps to implement this countermeasure:

  1. Understand Zonal NEGs: Zonal NEGs represent groups of service endpoints in specific zones. Utilizing them allows your load balancer to send traffic to instances in the healthiest zones, thereby enhancing reliability and availability.
  2. Create Zonal NEGs: Configure zonal NEGs for your VM instances or services within the specified zones. This ensures that traffic is efficiently directed to appropriate active endpoints in each zone.
  3. Integrate with Load Balancer: After configuring zonal NEGs, integrate them with your HTTP(S) Load Balancer. This ensures that requests are routed based on proximity and health, leveraging Google's global network effectively. The HTTP(S) Load Balancer setup guide provides step-by-step instructions for this configuration.
  4. Monitor and Adjust: Once integrated, continuously monitor the traffic distribution and instances' health status across zones. Use GCP's monitoring tools to adjust NEG configurations for optimal performance and to address any potential bottlenecks. More information can be found in the Cloud Monitoring documentation.

Implementing zonal NEGs helps maintain a resilient and performant architecture by providing geographically distributed endpoints for handling application loads. For additional security and best practices, refer to the overall HTTP(S) Load Balancing best practices document.

countermeasure.name: Control access and ensure Least Privilege to Cloud Load Balancing
countermeasure.desc:
To ensure secure access to Cloud Load Balancing services, implement IAM access control and apply the principle of least privilege. Begin by identifying the specific roles and permissions required for users interacting with Cloud Load Balancing. Assign these roles using the IAM & Admin section in the Google Cloud Console, ensuring that users and service accounts have only the permissions essential for their functions.

Consult the official Google Cloud IAM documentation to understand predefined roles that could be used to restrict access effectively. Use custom IAM roles if predefined roles do not meet your organization's specific needs.
Be cautious when granting the roles like roles/owner or roles/editor, as they provide broad access to resources.

Regularly review IAM policies by setting up audits and monitoring using IAM audit logs to identify potential over-privileged access. Periodically adjust permissions to align with current job responsibilities and security policies, removing unnecessary rights from users who no longer require them.

Incorporate the best practice guidelines from the Load Balancing Best Practices document to ensure robust security postures for load balancing activities. Regularly update your knowledge and practices according to the most current recommendations provided by Google Cloud.

countermeasure.name: Enable connection draining on Load Balancers
countermeasure.desc:
To ensure the graceful completion of ongoing requests during maintenance or shutdown of backend instances in GCP Load Balancing, you should configure connection draining. Connection draining allows existing connections to finish processing before the instance is terminated, thus preventing disruption in service and improving reliability.

Here is a step-by-step guidance on implementing connection draining:

  1. Access Google Cloud Console: Sign in to your Google Cloud Console.

  2. Navigate to Load Balancing: In the console, select Network services and then Load balancing.

  3. Choose the Load Balancer: Locate the load balancer you wish to modify by selecting it from the available list.

  4. Edit Backend Service: Under the selected load balancer, navigate to the Backend configuration tab and click on the backend service that you want to set up connection draining for.

  5. Configure Connection Draining: In the backend service settings, set the desired connection draining timeout value, which defines how long the load balancer will wait for current connections to end before forcefully closing them. Ensure this timeout period aligns with your application's expected request duration for optimal results.

  6. Save and Apply Changes: After setting the connection draining timeout, save your changes and allow the load balancer to refresh its configuration.

For further details and the most updated procedures on configuring connection draining within GCP Load Balancing, please refer to the official documentation available at GCP Connection Draining.

countermeasure.name: Enable logging of load balancing health checks
countermeasure.desc:
To ensure comprehensive visibility into the performance and status of your Cloud Load Balancers, it is essential to enable logging for health checks. This measure will allow you to monitor the operational health of backend services and promptly detect any issues.

To implement logging for health checks in Google Cloud Load Balancing, follow these steps:

  1. Enable Google Cloud Logging: Begin by ensuring that Google Cloud Logging is enabled for your Google Cloud project. This service will aggregate log data, including health check logs, for analysis and monitoring. More details can be found in the Google Cloud Logging documentation.
  2. Configure Logging in Load Balancer: Navigate to your load balancer settings in the Google Cloud Console. For HTTP(S) Load Balancers, set up or edit your existing load balancer and proceed to enable logging under the backend services or backend buckets. Refer to the step-by-step guide on configuring a load balancer for assistance.
  3. Verify and Specify Logging Parameters: Once logging is activated, verify that the appropriate log types are being captured. Typically, you should log both successful and failed health checks to obtain a comprehensive view of your load balancer's performance.
  4. Monitor and Review Logs: Utilize Google Cloud's operations suite to actively monitor and review health check logs. This will help you identify trends, troubleshoot issues, and ensure optimal performance.

By carefully enabling and configuring logging for health checks, you can improve security, optimize performance, and ensure the reliability of your Cloud Load Balancers.

countermeasure.name: Securely store your credentials and rotate Google Service account keys
countermeasure.desc:
To ensure the security of your GCP Load Balancing setup, it's imperative to manage and protect sensitive credentials such as service account keys effectively. Using Google Cloud's Secret Manager simplifies the storage and management of these secrets securely. Here are the steps to implement this countermeasure:

  1. Store Service Account Keys Securely:
    • Navigate to the Google Cloud Console and access the Secret Manager service.
    • Create a new secret to store your Google service account key. Upload the JSON key file and configure versioning if needed.
    • Restrict access to the secret by setting appropriate IAM policies, allowing only necessary users and services access.
  2. Configure Automatic Rotation:
    • Set up secret rotation by following the guidelines outlined in Managing Secrets documentation.
    • Enable the automatic rotation feature by specifying a rotation schedule, ensuring that secrets are rotated periodically to minimize exposure risks.
  3. Update Load Balancing Configuration:
    • Ensure that your load balancing configuration references service account keys securely stored in Secret Manager.
    • Reload or refresh configurations to apply new key versions after rotation, thus maintaining uninterrupted secure operations.

Implementing these measures enhances the security posture of your Google Cloud Platform services by reducing the attack surface associated with exposed credentials. For further details, refer to the HTTP(S) Load Balancing best practices.

countermeasure.name: Use Identity-Aware Proxy (IAP)
countermeasure.desc:
To enhance security and control access to your applications behind Google Cloud Load Balancers, implement Identity-Aware Proxy (IAP). IAP provides secure, perimeter-less access control to your web applications hosted on Google Cloud, ensuring that only authenticated and authorized users can access your services.

Step-by-Step Guidance for Cloud Engineers:

  1. Enable IAP API: Begin by enabling the Identity-Aware Proxy API in your Google Cloud Platform project. This can be done via the GCP Console or using the command line.
    • Console: Navigate to APIs & Services > Library and enable the IAP API.
    • Command Line: Use the following command: 
      gcloud services enable iap.googleapis.com
  2. Configure OAuth consent screen: Set up your OAuth consent screen to declare what resources your application will access and who can use it. This is required to use IAP as it relies on OAuth 2.0.
    • Navigate to API & Services > Credentials > OAuth consent screen. Configure the necessary information like application name, support email, and authorized domains.
  3. Define IAP-secured Resources: Identify the load balancers and the associated backend services you wish to secure with IAP. Ensure all requests to these resources are routed through the IAP.
  4. Configure Backend Services for IAP: Ensure your backend service is compatible with IAP. This requires using HTTPS for communication with the backend.
  5. Set up Access Controls: Define access policies to manage which user and group accounts can access your applications via IAP. Use IAM roles to grant permissions appropriately. Test Configuration: After setting up IAP, thoroughly test it to ensure that the authentication and authorization mechanisms are functioning as expected. Attempt to access the application both with and without the required permissions to verify that access controls are correctly enforced.

By implementing Identity-Aware Proxy with your GCP Load Balancers, you add an extra layer of security by enforcing application-level security policies without relying on a traditional perimeter-based network security model.

usecase.name: Denial of Service
usecase.desc: Denial of Service attacks aim to disrupt the availability of services or resources to legitimate users. Attackers overwhelm systems with excessive traffic or requests, causing them to become unresponsive or unavailable to users.

threat.name: Unmonitored load balancing health status
threat.desc:
General threat description
Lack of visibility into the health of Load Balancers can lead to undetected failures or vulnerabilities.
Threat agents/Attack vectors
Threat agents may include unauthorized users or attackers who exploit the lack of monitoring and visibility in order to introduce vulnerabilities, causing failures or performance issues that go unnoticed.
Impacts
The impacts of this threat can include failure to detect and resolve issues promptly, potentially leading to degraded performance, increased downtime, and susceptibility to attacks or exploits that could have been prevented with proper monitoring.
Example Attack Scenarios
An example involves an attacker exploiting a vulnerability that goes unnoticed due to insufficient health monitoring, allowing them to cause a denial of service attack by overloading the server resources, leaving legitimate users unable to access services.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1490 - Inhibit System Recovery

threat.name: Unrestricted network access
threat.desc:
General threat description
Allowing inbound traffic from all sources can significantly expose your system to a variety of attacks, leading to potential security breaches.
Threat agents/Attack vectors
Threat agents may include malicious actors who take advantage of unrestricted access to attempt unauthorized entry or launch DDoS attacks.
Impacts
Potential impacts include service disruption, unauthorized access to sensitive data, resource exhaustion, and increased vulnerability to DDoS attacks.
Example Attack Scenarios
An attacker could exploit this vulnerability by flooding the network with illegitimate traffic, causing a denial of service for legitimate users. Alternatively, a hacker might gain unauthorized access to internal systems by exploiting open ports.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1190 - Exploit Public-Facing Application

threat.name: Service fisruption furing Load Balancer maintenance
threat.desc:
General threat description
Lack of proper draining configurations during load balancer maintenance can result in abrupt terminations of active connections. This can affect service availability and lead to interrupted user sessions.
Threat agents/Attack vectors
Threat agents may include system administrators who fail to configure connection draining settings, as well as automated systems or scripts executing maintenance tasks without adequately managing active connections.
Impacts
The impact includes potential disruption of online services, loss of user data in transit, and negative user experience. This can further result in loss of revenue and damage to service reputation.
Example Attack Scenarios
An administrator schedules routine maintenance on the load balancer without enabling connection draining. As a result, active sessions are dropped abruptly, leading to loss of user activity data and complaints from users of interrupted services.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1499 - Endpoint Denial of Service

threat.name: Inefficient load distribution across zones
threat.desc:
General threat description
Poor configuration of Load Balancers can result in unequal resource allocation across various zones, which may negatively impact performance and availability.
Threat agents/Attack vectors
Malicious actors or system administrators who lack knowledge or make errors in the configuration of load balancers.
Impacts
This can lead to significant performance degradation and potential downtime, affecting user experience and business operations.
Example Attack Scenarios
A security administrator erroneously configures a load balancer to route all traffic to a single zone, overwhelming it and causing service delays or outages.

usecase.name: Elevation of Privilege
usecase.desc: Elevation of privilege involves an attacker gaining higher levels of access or permissions than intended. By exploiting vulnerabilities, attackers can escalate their privileges within a system to perform unauthorized actions or access sensitive data.

threat.name: Unauthorized access to Cloud Load Balancing
threat.desc:
General threat description
Improper access control may allow unauthorized users to configure or misuse Cloud Load Balancing, leading to potential disruptions or attacks.
Threat agents/Attack vectors
Unauthorized users exploiting misconfigured access controls to gain access to Cloud Load Balancing settings.
Impacts
Potential disruptions, data breaches, or service unavailability due to unauthorized configuration changes or misuse.
Example Attack Scenarios
An attacker gains access to a poorly configured load balancer and reroutes traffic, causing an outage or redirects users to a malicious site.

threat.name: Compromised credentials and key management
threat.desc:
General threat description
Failure to properly secure credentials and rotate keys increases the risk of unauthorized access, potentially leading to security breaches in cloud infrastructure.
Threat agents/Attack vectors
Malicious actors or insiders who gain access to unsecured or outdated credentials can exploit this vulnerability to infiltrate cloud resources.
Impacts
Unauthorized access can result in data breaches, loss of sensitive information, and disruption of services, ultimately damaging the organization's reputation and causing financial loss.
Example Attack Scenarios
An attacker discovers static credentials hardcoded in an application and uses them to access sensitive cloud resources. Additionally, a former employee uses unexpired credentials to access critical systems, leading to data exfiltration.

usecase.name: Information Disclosure
usecase.desc: Information disclosure occurs when sensitive data is exposed to unauthorized parties. This can include unauthorized access to confidential information, such as personal data, financial records, or intellectual property.

threat.name: Unauthorized access to applications behind load balancers
threat.desc:
General threat description
Improper access control can lead to unauthorized access to backend applications through load balancing, potentially exposing sensitive data and compromising application integrity.
Threat agents/Attack vectors
Malicious users or insiders may exploit misconfigurations in access control settings of the load balancer to gain unauthorized access to backend systems.
Impacts
Unauthorized access may result in data breaches, loss of sensitive information, and diminished trust in system security.
Example Attack Scenarios
An attacker discovers and exploits a misconfigured load balancer rule that lacks proper access control restrictions, allowing them to directly interact with critical backend systems without authentication.

weakness.name: CWE-306
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-306: Missing Authentication for Critical Function The product does not perform any authentication for functionality that requires a provable user identity or consumes a significant amount of resources.

weakness.name: CWE-326
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-326: Inadequate Encryption Strength The product stores or transmits sensitive data using an encryption scheme that is theoretically sound, but is not strong enough for the level of protection required. A weak encryption scheme can be subjected to brute force attacks that have a reasonable chance of succeeding using current attack methods and resources.

weakness.name: CWE-494
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-494: Download of Code Without Integrity Check The product downloads source code or an executable from a remote location and executes the code without sufficiently verifying the origin and integrity of the code. An attacker can execute malicious code by compromising the host server, performing DNS spoofing, or modifying the code in transit.

countermeasure.name: Automatically apply security patches to SQLServer instances
countermeasure.desc:
To minimize the risk of security vulnerabilities, configure SQLServer instances in GCP to automatically receive and apply security patches. Keeping SQLServer instances up to date with the latest security patches is essential in addressing newly discovered vulnerabilities and protecting your data from potential exploits. Automatic patching reduces the need for manual intervention and ensures that critical updates are applied promptly, helping to maintain a secure environment.

In GCP, you can enable automatic patching for your SQLServer instances through the Google Cloud Console or by configuring patch management policies. Regular patching reduces the attack surface by addressing known vulnerabilities, making your SQLServer instances less susceptible to attacks. Additionally, monitoring patching schedules and verifying the successful application of patches should be part of your routine security operations to ensure continuous protection.

References:

  • Google Cloud SQL Maintenance for SQL Server

countermeasure.name: Enable Transparent Data Encryption (TDE) for SQLServer data and logs
countermeasure.desc:
Transparent Data Encryption (TDE) is a security feature that automatically encrypts SQLServer data files and logs at rest, ensuring the protection of sensitive information stored in your SQLServer instances. By enabling TDE, all data written to disk is encrypted, including database backups and transaction logs, which helps to prevent unauthorized access to data through physical storage theft or breaches. TDE also provides automatic encryption without requiring changes to applications, simplifying the implementation process.

In GCP, encryption at rest is automatically managed for SQLServer instances to safeguard your data and maintain compliance with data protection regulations. This ensures that sensitive data remains encrypted at all times, reducing the risk of exposure in case of security incidents. You can enhance security by using customer-managed encryption keys (CMEK) to maintain control over the encryption process. Regularly auditing encryption status and key usage will help ensure the ongoing security of your data at rest.

References:

  • Google Cloud SQL for SQL Server Documentation
  • Google Cloud Encryption at Rest

countermeasure.name: Encrypt SQLServer backups to secure backup and restore processes
countermeasure.desc:
Ensure that all SQLServer backups are encrypted to protect data during both backup and restore procedures. Unencrypted backups are vulnerable to unauthorized access, especially when stored or transferred. By applying encryption to SQLServer backups, sensitive data is safeguarded against potential threats, ensuring that even if the backup files are intercepted or improperly accessed, the data remains protected and unreadable.

In GCP, SQLServer backups can be automatically encrypted using various encryption options, such as customer-managed encryption keys (CMEK) or Google-managed encryption keys. Implementing encryption for backups should be part of your broader data protection strategy, ensuring that the security of your SQLServer data extends beyond its operational environment.

References:

  • Google Cloud SQL for SQL Server Documentation
  • Cloud SQL - Backup and Restore
  • Google Cloud Encryption at Rest

standard.ref: SC-12 CRYPTOGRAPHIC KEY ESTABLISHMENT AND MANAGEMENT

countermeasure.name: Integrate SQL Server with Google Cloud IAM for identity and access management
countermeasure.desc:
Integrating Cloud SQL for SQL Server instances with Google Cloud Identity and Access Management (IAM) allows for centralized and secure management of access to your SQL Server instances. By leveraging IAM, you can assign fine-grained permissions to specific users, groups, or service accounts, ensuring that only authorized personnel can interact with your SQL Server resources. This integration helps enforce the principle of least privilege, where each user or service is given only the minimum level of access required to perform their job functions.

Additionally, Google Cloud IAM provides role-based access controls (RBAC) and policies that allow you to define precise access controls based on job functions, ensuring compliance with security policies and regulatory requirements. The integration also facilitates comprehensive logging of access and modification events, which is essential for audit trails and compliance checks. Regularly reviewing these access logs will help you identify potential security risks or unauthorized attempts to access sensitive data stored in SQL Server instances. Implementing IAM integration reduces the risk of credential misuse and strengthens your overall security posture.

References:

  • Google Cloud SQL for SQL Server Documentation
  • Google Cloud IAM Overview
